table.name: mem
table.column: On {TKW p.59:src}, it is explained one's face is shown as a symbol of identity or honor. See also {cha' qabDu':n} and {qabDu' law':n} for idiomatic uses of this word.

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression refers to a group participating in a single activity. For example, a brawl may be described by saying {Suv qabDu' law':sen:nolink} "Many faces are fighting".
many people, a lot of people, lots of people, multitude, crowd

table.name: mem
table.column:
The {yor:n} of a {qach:n} is its {beb:n}, and its {Hur:n}-facing walls are called {reD:n:1}. The other side of the {beb:n} (that is, the {'aqroS:n:1} of a {qach:n}) is called the {pa' beb:n}; the {qoD:n} face of a {reD:n:1} is referred to as {pa' reD:n}.
For the {qoD:n} parts of a {qach:n}, see {pa':n:1}.

table.name: mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {ngup qaD:sen:nolink}, literally "challenge the cape", which describes someone who is unsatisfied with the status quo and wants to challenge those in charge. See {ngup:n}.[2, p.157]

table.name: mem
table.column: According to {A Burning House:src}, this is a raised, fenced platform in the plaza outside the headquarters of the {tlhIngan Hubbeq:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The names of the consonants consist of the sound followed by {ay:sen:nolink}, and the names of the vowels consist of the sound preceded by {':sen:nolink} and followed by {t:sen:nolink}. The glottal stop is an exception.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is often written in English as "gagh".
There is an idiom, {ghung; qagh rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "to kill gagh (serpent worms)", which should be eaten live. This idiomatic expression is applied to someone who is doing something counterproductive.
▶ {SuyDuj DaQaw'chugh qagh DaHoH.:sen:nolink} This indicates that destroying the merchant ship would be contrary to the best interests of the current mission.

table.name: mem
table.column: gagh stew, gagh served as leftovers

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is never heard except in direct address.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This word literally means "fiery lava" on Krios. It implies courage of a surprising or unexpected kind, perhaps even recklessness (unlike {toDuj:n} which is more neutral).[1, p.10]

table.name: mem
table.column: The parts of a foot include its {bem:n} "sole", {va'nuch:n} "heel", {mov:n} "top (of foot)", and {yaD:n:1} "toe(s)". The foot is attached to the {'uS:n} "leg" through the {ngIb:n} "ankle".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call a Terran bicycle.

table.name: mem
table.column: The body of the dead enemy lies in front of my feet.
Der Körper des toten Feindes liegt zu meinen Füßen.
This sentence does not appear in canon. It is included here because it is used in some fan ceremonies.

table.name: mem
table.column: MO accomodated by changing {qama'} to mean prisoner while {Star Trek III:src} was being filmed.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to legend, this is the name of an ancient village on {Qo'noS:n} where Kahless and Lukara fought a great battle against hundreds of enemies, a major component of their courtship.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The verb {muSHa':v} does not necessarily indicate romantic love, for which see the noun {parmaq:n}.
Contrary to some unreliable sources, the phrase "Urkuk lu Stalga" does not mean "I love you, baby" in Klingon. In fact, it is not Klingon at all. Calling someone a baby (see {ghu:n}) is not considered a sign of affection in Klingon.

table.name: mem
table.column:
Note that in Klingon, there is a different word for "be old (not new)" ({ngo':v}) than for "be old (not young)" ({qan:v:1,nolink}).
This word is applied to people and animals.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: An idiomatic gesture (due to homophony with {qan:v:1}): to point your pinkie at someone is to comment that you believe they are old.
▶ {qI'empeqDaq jIqan.} "I think that K'mpec is old."

table.name: mem
table.column: a bird known for its song
This is a reference to Conrad Birdie, the lead character in the musical Bye Bye Birdie.

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that {qanwI':n:nolink} can also mean "old person". An idiomatic gesture: to point your pinkie at someone is to comment that you believe they are old.

table.name: mem
table.column: always agree with, always cooperate with
▶ {jIHDaq Daqang.:sen:nolink} "You always agree with me, you always cooperate with me."[1, p.159]

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is used in forming tag questions with the suffix {-'a':v:suff}. In such a question, {qar'a':sen:nolink} either follows the verb, or comes at the end of the sentence. ({TKDA 6.4:src})

table.name: mem
table.column: Fire the torpedoes at my command!
Feuere die Torpedos auf meinem Kommando!

table.name: mem
table.column: The Cardassian Homeworld, the main planet of the Cardassian Union. Also called {qarDaSya':n:nolink}[1, p.141-142] and {qarDaS wa':n:nolink} (Cardassia Prime)[2].

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qarDaSQa'Daq ruDelya' rop'a' Hergh qengbogh yo' Dabot.:sen:nolink} "Intercept Rudellian plague relief convoy to Cardassian Union."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Vogel mit der Fähigkeit, Sprache zu imitieren
Some people pluralize this word with {-pu':n:suff}, but most use {-mey:n:suff}.

table.name: mem
table.column: bird capable of mimicking speech, larger than {qaryoq:n}
Vogel mit der Fähigkeit, Sprache zu imitieren, größer als {qaryoq:n}
Some people pluralize this word with {-pu':n:suff}, but most use {-mey:n:suff}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This sentence doesn't appear exactly in canon, but {qaStaH nuq jay'?:sen:nolink} "What the #$*@ is happening?" appears on {TKD p.177:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: qaStaHvIS wa' ram loS SaD Hugh SIjlaH qetbogh loD.
Four thousand throats may be cut in one night by a running man.
Ein Mann kann in einer Nacht viertausend Kehlen durchschneiden.

table.name: mem
table.column: qaStaHvIS wej puq poHmey vav puqloDpu' puqloDpu'chaj je quvHa'moH vav quvHa'ghach.
The dishonor of the father dishonors his sons and their sons for three generations.
Die Entehrung des Vaters entehrt seine Söhne und dessen Söhne für drei Generationen.
The dishonour of the father dishonours his sons and their sons for three generations.

table.name: mem
table.column: {qaSuj'a'?:sen:nolink} is how you would ask the question if you're speaking to only one person. To ask a group of people if you're disturbing them, say {SaSuj'a'?:sen:nolink} "Am I disturbing you (plural)?"

table.name: mem
table.column: Cats were mummified in ancient Egypt.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a reference to the "Why a Duck?" ("viaduct") routine from the Marx Brothers movie "The Cocoanuts". {Da'nal:n} and {Da'vI':n} are types of Klingon ducks. Also, "duck tape" or "duct tape" is a type of adhesive tape sometimes used in ductwork.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is used when addressing a single person. To salute multiple people, say {Savan!:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is used in {Klingon Monopoly:src} to denote how many {QaS:n:1h} a player has to pay when landing on a planet owned by another player.

table.name: mem
table.column: sich erinnern an, an etwas denken
▶ {bomDI' 'IwwIj qaqaw.:sen} ▶ {batlh Daqawlu'taH.:sen} "You will be remembered with honor."

table.name: mem
table.column:
Based on the example, the subject does the reminding, the object is the thing remembered, and the person who is reminded is marked with {-vaD:n}.
More generally, it seems that when {-moH:v} is added to a verb {X:sen:nolink} which takes an object, the resulting bivalent verb {XmoH:sen:nolink} takes the same object, while the original subject of {X:sen:nolink} becomes the beneficiary of {XmoH:sen:nolink} and is marked with {-vaD:n}.

▶ {qorDu'Daj tuq 'oS Ha'quj'e' tuQbogh wo'rIv. tuQtaHvIS Hem. ghaHvaD quHDaj qawmoH.:sen:nolink} "The sash that Worf wears is a symbol of his family's house. He wears it proudly as a reminder of his heritage."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: If someone is a {qay'wI'}, then you give them a {qaywI':n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: be a problem, be a hassle

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the Star Trek Encyclopedia, MO devised this phrase to honour Star Trek III visual-effects supervisor Ken Ralston and his ILM crew, who responded to every request with "No problem!"

table.name: mem
table.column:
The subject does the replacing, and the object is replaced.
This verb seems to have been derived from {qa'meH:n}, possibly through misinterpretation of what was originally the suffix {-qa':v}. Use this verb with caution, since it may not be accepted by all Klingon speakers (see {mu'mey ghoQ:n}).

▶ {Quj wa'DIch MONOPOLY Huch nav qa' tlhIngan QaS:sen:nolink} "Klingon forces replace original MONOPOLY bills" ▶ {Chance 'echletHommey Community Chest 'echletHommey je qa' quv 'echletHommey vIq 'echletHommey je:sen:nolink} "COMBAT and HONOR cards replace Chance and Community Chest cards" ▶ {Quj wa'DIch juH qachmey mebpa'mey je qa' raQmey chu' monmey chu' je:sen:nolink} "Custom OUTPOSTS and CAPITALS replace original Houses and Hotels"

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a sort of life force within a person which escapes when that person dies.[2]
This is an acceptable word to use for "ghost", but there may be another (and better) unknown word for that concept.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: We fight to enrich the spirit.
Wir kämpfen, um den Geist zu bereichern.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word was originally a shortened form of {quvqa'meH:sen:nolink} (see {qa'meH vIttlhegh:n}), but has since become accepted as a noun in its own right. It refers to something that takes over for or is used instead of something that is gone or which has been lost. To denote a temporary substitute or stand-in, use {lIw:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: In the past, this used to be {quvqa'meH vIttlhegh:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
Its claw is eaten. This word may also be spelled {Qa'raj:n:nolink}.
Do not confuse this with the similarly named {Qaj:n}.
On {KGT p.94:src}, this word is spelled {qa'raj:n:nolink}. However, it is spelled {Qa'raj:n:nolink} in both the E-K and K-E word lists.

table.name: mem
table.column: end (of corridor, tunnel, conduit, Jeffries tube, sewer, road, bridge, long field, etc.)
Ende (von Korridor, Tunnel, Rohrleitung, Jeffries-Röhre, Kanal, Straße, Brücke, langes Feld, usw.
This is the end of any clearly defined space longer than wide in which people might find themselves.

table.name: mem
table.column: sehr großer, schwarzer Vogel (viel größer als {notqa':n})
It is much larger than a {notqa':n}.
The character of Big Bird on the children's show Sesame Street is played by Caroll Edwin Spinney.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the Klingon code name for the Federation's Genesis weapons research project. Its meaning is otherwise unknown.
▶ {qa'vam De' vIje' rIntaH.:sen:nolink} "I have obtained the Genesis data."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: qa'vak (traditional game), game played with hoop and stick
It may just be a coincidence, but this sounds like {qa' vaQ:n:nolink} "aggressive spirit". See {qa':n} and {vaQ:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the action of squeezing the bag part of the {DIron:n}, usually with the elbow.[1, p.76]

table.name: mem
table.column: In the {paq'raD:n:nolink} "Force Book" of the {paq'batlh:n}, the second section is titled {qeHHa' loDnI':sen:nolink}, which is given the somewhat loose English translation "A Brother's Forgiveness". A footnote explains that the concept of forgiveness does not map exactly to Klingon culture, and that the literal meaning of the title is "A Brother Unresents". The title of the corresponding canto in the opera {'u':n:name,nolink} is {loDnI'Daj quvqa'moH:sen:nolink}, literally, "he causes the brother to have honor again".

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a unit of measurement roughly akin to two kilometers.

table.name: mem
table.column: In the {paq'batlh:src}, the {qempa'QeH:n:nolink} are the enraged (see {QeH:v}) ancestral spirits populating {ghe'tor:n}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: a while back, a long time ago?
This word does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

table.name: mem
table.column: A pregnant woman is said to {qeng:v:nolink} a {puq:n}.[2] See {yatlh:v}.

▶ {yatlh luqara' puqloD wa'DIch qenglI'} "Lukara, pregnant of their first-born son"[2] ▶ {qarDaSQa'Daq ruDelya' rop'a' Hergh qengbogh yo' Dabot.:sen:nolink} "Intercept Rudellian plague relief convoy to Cardassian Union."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: annual meeting of Klingon speakers in Germany

The {qepHom'a':n:nolink} is the annual Klingon Language meeting in Saarbrücken, Germany. Please visit their web site at {www.qepHom.de:url:http://www.qepHom.de/} for more information.
The official annual conference of the Klingon Language Institute is known as the {qep'a':n}, while other gatherings of Klingonists are known as {qepHommey:n:nolink}. The meeting in Saarbrücken, Germany, is the largest {qepHom:n:nolink} (and it sometimes even has more participants than the {qep'a':n:nolink}). For this reason, it is called {qepHom'a':n:nolink}. Its name contains an intentional ungrammaticality: two type 1 noun suffixes.
This intentional use of improper grammar was approved by MO.

table.name: mem
table.column: The {qep'a':n:nolink} is the official annual conference of the Klingon Language Institute ({tlhIngan Hol yejHaD:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column:
Also related are the suffixes {-rup:v} and {-beH:v}.
Do not confuse with {Qeq:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qaStaHvIS wa' ram loS SaD Hugh SIjlaH qetbogh loD.:sen}

table.name: mem
table.column: Soße, die aus verdickter Marinade besteht
This is sauce prepared by thickening {chanDoq:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In its first appearance as a noun, in {HQ 4.4, Dec. 1995:src}, {qev:n:nolink} was described as "[among] those words already well-known for different types of groups". The noun {tlhach:n} was explicitly introduced as being a new word in the same article. This suggests that the verb {qev:v} was misread as a noun.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a traded commodity, like {DIlyum:n}.
This is described in {The Star Trek Encyclopedia:src} as a type of gemstone.

table.name: mem
table.column:
Kahless is the legendary first Klingon Emperor who united the Klingon people.
He is commonly known as "Kahless the Unforgettable" ({qeylIS'e' lIjlaHbe'bogh vay':sen:nolink}[2] or {qeylIS lIjlaHbogh pagh:sen:nolink}[3]).

table.name: mem
table.column: This is abbreviated QB in the {paq'batlh:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is abbreviated QBV in the {paq'batlh:src}. (This could be a typo for QBN.)

table.name: mem
table.column: Eyes of Kahless, a game played with dice
This is a guessing game with dice in which the winner receives a punch.

table.name: mem
table.column: All fermented meat is known as {qeyvaq Ha'DIbaH:n:nolink}, with the word for the specific meat replacing the word {Ha'DIbaH:n:1}.
"Kiviak" is an Inuit food made of auks fermented in the body of a seal.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is what Klingons would call the Terran vegetable.

table.name: mem
table.column: This was apparently intended to be {qIb:n} plus {HeH:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In English slang, to "kid" is to joke.

table.name: mem
table.column: joke, make a joke, tell a joke
In English slang, to "kid" is to joke.

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb always takes an object or {-chuq:v} in normal usage.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: "Kill". This is defined in {TKD:src} only as "cancel". The "abort" meaning was given at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a city, where {qeylIS:n} once witnessed a foolish man stand outside the walls during a fierce storm in an attempt to make the wind respect him.

table.name: mem
table.column: While this word is known only as the name of a ship class, it seems likely that it also refers to a bird or to a class of predatory birds (cf. {toQ:n}).

This is "Jurassic" spelled backwards.
In the {Haynes BoP Manual:src}, this ship class is referred to as {raptor:n:nolink} in Klingon, but this is likely a placeholder which was overlooked by mistake.

table.name: mem
table.column: The sentence from {SkyBox 15:src} has the {wa'DIch:n} in the wrong place. Also, the second occurrence of {vatlh DIS poH:n} is missing a space.

table.name: mem
table.column: Arrows come from "quiv"ers, and you can take an arrow to the knee.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to a message on the {msn:src} newsgroup, Maltz seemed reluctant to talk about what exactly this is.[2]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: ▶ {qI'empeqDaq jIqan.} "I think that K'mpec is old."

table.name: mem
table.column:
This both holds up one's {yopwaH:n} and is used for hanging weapons.[2]
{qoghmey:n:nolink} generally means "belts", but could also mean "ears scattered all about", due to the homophony with {qogh:n:2}. This homophony is also the basis of a slang expression, {qogh tuQmoHHa':sen}.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This refers to the external flap of skin, cartilage, or whatever. The internal organ of hearing is called {teS:n}.
{qoghDu':n:nolink} can only mean "ears", while {qoghmey:n:nolink} is usually the plural of {qogh:n:1} and means "belts". The homophony between these two words is the basis of a slang expression, {qogh tuQmoHHa':sen}.[2]
This is a reference to the painter Vincent van Gogh, who cut off his ear.

table.name: mem
table.column: This construction doesn't appear in canon, but during a discussion of {qorghwI':n} at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2013:src}, everyone immediately knew what it meant.

table.name: mem
table.column: This expression literally means "take off one's belt". It derives its slang meaning from the homophony between {qogh:n:1} and {qogh:n:2}.
It's unclear why the expression is {tuQmoHHa':sen:nolink} and not {tuQHa'moH:v}.
▶ {qogh vItuQmoHHa'pu':sen:nolink} "I've taken off my belt; your secret is safe with me."

table.name: mem
table.column: The wind does not respect a fool.
Der Wind nimmt keine Rücksicht auf einen Narren.

table.name: mem
table.column: This name is untranslated in {KGT:src}, and is possibly a misspelling for {qo'leq:n:name}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
According to Klingon legend, Kotar was the first Klingon. He and his mate slew the gods, and he now ferries the souls of the dishonored to Gre'thor ({ghe'tor:n}) on the Barge of the Dead ({Hegh Duj:n}).
This name is sometimes written as Kortar ({qortar:n:name,nolink}).

table.name: mem
table.column: To prepare this, {tap:v} a mixture of {naH:n} and animal matter, and let {rogh:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word is used for the act of composing songs, stories, etc.[2, p.71] Klingons consider songs as things which just exist, and the act of composition is viewed as hunting down, trapping, and logging them.[3]
There is another verb, {gher:v}, which is used for compiling lists and the like, and which, in contrast to {qon:v:nolink}, suggests that information is merely passed along.[4]
This is defined as "record" in {TKD:src}, and as "compose" in {KGT:src}.[1; 2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that {qonwI':n:nolink} can also mean a recording device, as in {mIllogh qonwI':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In English, "cop" is a slang term for a police officer.

table.name: mem
table.column: A {yoqqoq} would, of course, be a "so-called humanoid".
This word does not appear in canon. This entry is here for ease of reference only.

table.name: mem
table.column: The Klingon sentence on {SkyBox 13:src} seems to have dropped some words, since it is ungrammatical.
[1] {TKD:src}, [2] {SkyBox 13:src} (reprinted in {HQ 3.4, p.10-11, Dec. 1994:src}), [3] {SkyBox 20:src} (reprinted in {HQ 5.2, p.14, Jun. 1996:src})

table.name: mem
table.column: Unlike {teb:v}, this indicates stopping up an opening, but not filling up the inside.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to the cork or stopper of a bottle, such as a wine bottle.

table.name: mem
table.column: According to the glossary to {A Burning House:src}, this is a rodent that is considered a destructive pest on Klingon farms, where farmers have to set traps for them.

table.name: mem
table.column: This literally means "may you enjoy your birthday!" To wish a happy birthday to multiple people, say {qoSraj botIvjaj!}

table.name: mem
table.column: While this word has appeared in canon only in reference to ribbon-like recording media, it refers to their form, rather than to their function.[2] It may be thought of as a flat version of {SIrgh:n}.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: From the {BoP:src} poster, {qughDo motlh:n:nolink} is "normal cruising speed".

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {qorDu'Daj tuq 'oS Ha'quj'e' tuQbogh wo'rIv. tuQtaHvIS Hem. ghaHvaD quHDaj qawmoH.:sen:nolink} "The sash that Worf wears is a symbol of his family's house. He wears it proudly as a reminder of his heritage."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {jIbDaj lumeQmoH qul bIQtIq qulHommey:sen:nolink} "Sparks from the fire river caught his hair"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to pieces of animal skin soaked in liquor and set on fire, which must be eaten quickly.

table.name: mem
table.column: Beeil dich! Komm in die Pötte!
This idiomatic expression literally means "Eat the fire skin!"

table.name: mem
table.column: This term isn't actually explicitly defined in the {paq'bath:src}, but is just used this way.

table.name: mem
table.column: House of Fire, name of an opera
Haus des Feuers, Name einer Oper

table.name: mem
table.column: History is written by the victors.
Geschichte wird geschrieben durch die Sieger.

table.name: mem
table.column: hole (like a hole in a musical instrument)

Based on the explanation in {HQ 10.2:src}, this seems to refer to a hole used to change pitch in a wind instrument, and apparently not to a soundhole for a stringed instrument. However, this is not explicitly stated.[1]
This word can't be used for a hole in the ground (for which see {QemjIq:n}), but it can be used for a bullet hole or a hole in a shirt (including buttonholes, moth holes, accidental rips, etc.). The difference between a {QemjIq:n} and a {qung:n:nolink} is that the former can be filled ({teb:v}).[2]
Possibly based on the Chinese "kǒng" (孔), also meaning hole.

table.name: mem
table.column: The subjects are the events that happen simultaneously.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is allegedly the Morskan term for an architect. The {ta' Hol:n} term is {renwI':n}.
This word was suggested by Quvar to MO as a new word for the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src}. It's based on the name of the Swiss-born French architect Le Corbusier.

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression literally means "to sit in a chair". It is based on the homophony between {ba':v} and {-ba':v:suff}.
▶ {quSDaq bIba'.:sen:nolink} "What you said is quite obvious."

table.name: mem
table.column: There is a typo in this sentence in {TKD:src}, an extraneous space after {ba':sen:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This weapon is associated symbolically with assassins.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a ceremony in which a young Klingon draws blood for first time.[1, p.62]

table.name: mem
table.column:
This word refers to personal honor, which is earned by one's behaviour, and can be bestowed, in contrast to {batlh:n}.[2]
Note that {ghaj:v} and {Hutlh:v} can be used with this noun to indicate that someone possesses or lacks honor, respectively.

▶ {quv lughaj Archer HoD beqDaj je. lengtaH 'e' yIchaw'.:sen:nolink} "Captain Archer and his crew are honorable people. Let them continue on their way."[3] ▶ {quv Hutlh HoHbogh tlhIngan 'ach qabDaj 'angbe'bogh.:sen}[4]

table.name: mem
table.column: be honoured, be honourable, be revered

table.name: mem
table.column: A {quv bey':n:nolink} has two {betleH:n} and two {Daqtagh:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The Klingon who kills without showing his face has no honor.
Ein Klingone, der tötet ohne sein Gesicht zu zeigen, hat keine Ehre.
The Klingon who kills without showing his face has no honour.

table.name: mem
table.column: Klingon has more specific words to describe dishonor, which depend on the circumstances of the dishonor. If the honor paid to someone is unearned or undeserved, consider {HoQ:v}. If the dishonor involves deception about one's social status, consider {Qaq:v}. If it involves a fall from grace, consider {mIl:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is simply {quv:v} plus the suffix {-moH:v}, so verb suffixes of types 1 to 3 need to go before {-moH:v}, which is type 4. However, this rule is sometimes broken for rhetorical effect.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of the Ferengi bartender on the Federation space station Deep Space Nine.
▶ {quwargh tach Qe' je qoDDaq Hov leng Soj DatIv.} "Enjoy Star Trek themed food and drink at Quark's Bar and Restaurant."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: Note that the reverse, {pI'yuq:sen:nolink}, is phonetically "puke".

table.name: mem
table.column: This verb is typically applied only to people or animals. When applied to something other than a person or an animal, it is likely that its slang meaning (see {qu':v:2}) is intended.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: be great, be wonderful, be excellent, be splendid

When this verb is applied to a person or an animal, it is not always clear whether the slang or literal meaning (see {qu':v:1}) is intended. However, when applied to something other than a person or an animal, the slang meaning is more likely.[1, p.159]
Two out-of-fashion slang words with the same meaning are {Huv:v:2,slang} and {nong:v:2,slang}, the latter of which may be making a comeback.[1, p.161]

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Gamma Quadrant.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a geometric pyramid ({'Impey':n}) with a three-sided base ({ra'Duch:n}).
"Khufu", also known as Cheops, is the Egyptian pharaoh generally thought to have built the Great Pyramid of Giza.
